author: ALEKYZ

description.text:
Also available for purchase at http://etsy.me/13dGeQG
I used Emmett's rotating gear code from the heart gear, and mashed it up with the CT scanned skull. I tried a few orientations, I like this one the most because it splits down the middle of the face.

Print out the center, 4 sets of pins, and one of each gear. Snap together, rotate, and marvel.
This was printed on my Up!, I haven't tried it yet on the Replicator. I printed using support, because of an overhang on the eye socket.
EDIT 8/2/12 So I accidentally had uploaded an earlier version of the skull. It should still have come together, but would look a little different from the picture. I have now uploaded the newer version.

comments.text: I needed a nice large raft for first layer, and I used the "bones" from the other heart gear files I have. Otherwise, I'm extremely happy with this print!
comments.author: JungleStyx

comments.text: Great !!
comments.author: shred66

comments.text: What program was used to create this model?
comments.author: ImperatorRex

comments.text: Thanks for your note! "openscad" is the program used to create it. In fact it was quite easy to modify the original program used to make a heart gear into a skull gear -- I just needed to put the skull STL in the right orientation, and then re-calculate everything on that instead of the heart! If you are familiar with computer programming, you will feel right at home with OpenSCAD -- otherwise though it might be a little intimidating.
comments.author: ImperatorRex

comments.text: I must try this! Do you think you could make a Darth Vader or Yoda gear skull? That would be AWESOME!!!
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: Had to use hot glue to glue down the first few layers or else it lifts later.
comments.author: RemeberMe

comments.text: Are there any instructions about how to assemble this puppy? I'm worried that once attach a piece I will not be able to detach it from the clips.  Which sized clips go to which gear? and on which side of the center piece?  Thanks!
comments.author: AveryBellis

comments.text: We don't have any visual instructions made for this right now. But, the clips are definitely re-attachable, so as long as you avoid the superglue you shouldn't have any problems.
comments.author: AveryBellis

comments.text: Very Helpful! thank you!
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: In the made section I added one yesterday with shots of every angle. This might help you see where all the gears go. It's the white one on the black board with a white grid.
comments.author: AveryBellis

comments.text: Do you need support printing the large ocular gears?
comments.author: Grimarr

comments.text: Hey,
comments.author: Grimarr

comments.text: I have a Printrbot Simple and use Repetier-host V0.95F with slic3r. I have already printed everything but 2,4, and 6. I am printing 6 right now.
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: Since your work is a remix of two others that both have ShareAlike in their license, doesn't your work need to be licensed ShareAlike as well?
comments.author: appdev007

comments.text: Ah, you're totally right! Thanks for the heads up -- license has been updated.
comments.author: appdev007

comments.text: Oh and in case you didn't know, your design is being sold on Amazon's new 3D printing store:
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: Thanks! Yep, that's actually us printing and shipping them :). Amazon does not let us put external links anywhere, so for attribution we're including all the info & links in with the packing slip.
comments.author: appdev007

comments.text: Hey I'm trying to print your skull out.  First I'd like to say it's a ridiculously cool looking model, and I can't wait to be able to assemble it!  Unfortunately, the pins that I've printed out are rather too large.  Were they meant to be printed in PLA or ABS?  The rest of the skull I've printed out in PLA, and I thought that using ABS would make the pins more flexible, and therefore easier to fit into the hole.  Should I reduce the size of the pins?  I know the setting of filament always causes a change in the size of things.
comments.author: dagudside

comments.text: I want to print this as one piece to make a gear shift knob. I have the nylon. Does anyone know an easy way for a newbie to assemble this as a solid print and maybe add a base to drill and tap for the shifter? This would be the ultimate gift for a gear head!
comments.author: MrPTrog

comments.text: Cool idea! Hm, so you would not need the gears to rotate then? What sort of printer do you have? I imagine you will have lots of difficulties with support if you try to print it out all as one piece.. why not print them separately and assemble, but add some super glue if you want it to stay solid & together?
comments.author: MrPTrog

comments.text: is it possible to mod this code so it would be a tardis i tried but completely failed.
comments.author: lookwhatjoeysmaking

comments.text: Yeah it should be possible! You just need to have a solid-body to intersect with. The tardis version probably failed because the popular tardis model is hollow in the center. If you close up the center, then it'll probably work. Though, it might work better if you shrink the tardis along the Z axis so it is closer to a square.. Let me know if you need help.
comments.author: lookwhatjoeysmaking

comments.text: Printed at 50% reduced size.Â  See photo attached.Â  Pins tend to be a little loose, but still in all, it worked.Â  Pretty cool - thanks!!!
comments.author: Hammerhead

comments.text: So, I'm curious, what was your process/workflow for generating this. Â i.e., details beyond you mashed up the heart gear and the skull. Â Any details would be appreciated.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: Â Hello, I'm sorry I missed this! I used the Emmett's openscad code for the screwless heart gear (this thing's derivative).Â  When you load the code into openscad, there are lots of the useful functions which perform this "mashing up". Effectively, you are intersecting this "rotating gear" mechanism with another shape. Try it first with a sphere or cube, and see how the rendering changes as you rotate and move the sphere or cube about (you can do this in another program; I used blender to export the STLs to be loaded into openscad).
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: I've printed out three of these, white/bone, black, and yellow. Â It's a perfect design for Halloween. Â Assembly was easy but took a little readjusting of position to get the fit just right, i.e., a "smooth" skull.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: So the pins might need to be a little bigger for a multi-material print.  But I like how it turned out!  Thanks for creating it, and I uploaded a picture with the parts and pieces so you could see it.
comments.author: WI_3DPrinter

comments.text: Any assembly instructions?  I printed the gears on a ZCorp 650, and the pins on a 3D Systems Projet 3000.  The first pin file was corrupt, so I had to reload it.  After I CA the gears I'm looking to snap it together with the Projet printed pins.  Just wondering about how to snap it all together?  Orientation on the center would be helpful!
comments.author: WI_3DPrinter

comments.text: Hey! Oh interesting, I wonder how it looks on the ZCorp compared to the commodity machines. Assembly is similar to the heart gear from which this was derived.
comments.author: WI_3DPrinter

comments.text: I love this thing! I'm having difficulty putting the three small gears in the proper orientation. When I look at the picture you have, the front small gear piece (with the nasal bone) is different than what prints out on the skull 1357 file. When I print out that file, none of the pieces has the distinctive nasal bone.
comments.author: Narsil

comments.text: Hey -- thanks for the heads up! You are right, I had accidentally uploaded an early version with the skull at a different orientation, so the pieces look slightly different from the picture. Your print should still come together as it is, but a little different from the picture.
comments.author: Narsil

comments.text: SWEEEET! printing this right now! NOW!
comments.author: sirmakesalot

I planned to investigate, design, make and evaluate a prototype book shelf organizer that will keep student books and papers in place and allow me to label the subject area clearly so that it is organized and that I can easily tell which subjects I am looking at. I feel I have accomplished this on the design. The product was aimed at high school students (both male and female between the ages of 16-18) with large bookshelves in their rooms to help with storage. However it may be applicable for a wider range of people?s storage needs. The product over all, not only accommodates the high school students with lots of books, but also a wider variety of people who need to store book.

The only process that was used in the manufacture of this product was laser cutting of acrylic. I designed various prototypes and finally came to this conclusion. The book holder/divider allows users to organize and store books in their messy bookshelves, or on their desks in a creative and innovative way.

comments.text: This would be perfect for my office space as I constantly need to use a range of books and this would be perfect to help me to organise these better.

Spool insert, take two.

As you can imagine, spoll insert is often the first thing, you've ever needed to print. So did I, but the first model was an ugly bin full of squared infill.

So this is another take, hollow object. Most of the infill has been taken out and the hole end is slightly angled to allow safe printing without any supports. The core infill can be tuned on print.

Maybe the supports are still too thick and could go with 2 layers only.

title: Low Poly Fantasy World - Base Tiles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Three little fantasy landscape pieces. A landspace with road, a forest and a cave cut neatly into triangle shapes.

Use them as Dungeons And Dragons 3D maps or make up your own tabletop game with them. They also look great as little pieces of a world on your desk or anywhere else where they might catch a eye.

Print a single one, print a set, print a cake, print a 3D map, print a whole low poly fantasy world.

Check out the other tiles here: https://www.thingiverse.com/Davision3d/collections/low-poly-fantasy-world
More are coming.

They originated from the video game Last Knight and its 3D map, check out the intro trailer where you fly through them: https://youtu.be/UoBhmJC8iQE
Or fly through the world yourself over at Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/4629b972551c4faf89e6dead5f5fe705
You can find the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/262210/Last_Knight_Rogue_Rider_Edition/

They can be printed in full color as well as regular single color. Or just paint them how you like.

The forest is also available for multi extruder printers. I was not able to test that, if you will print it with a dual extruder please let me know if it worked fine then I will also make the other pieces like that for multi extruder printer.

There are also little connection bits you can print so you can put them tightly together.

While I also created the Low Poly Fantasy Tabletop figures (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1244599) they are not compatible with the world pieces but you could always scale these tiles up to to match the figures though that would need to be lots bigger.

Notes:

There are versions with feets which improve the prints staying on the platform significantly. In case you don't have a heating platform I still recommend printing with a brim or just use a raft instead.

comments.text: These are some of the best multi-material prints I've seen. I love the low-poly look. Please add more! :)

description.text:
Randomized Hex Snowflakes with BlocksCAD

Working in BlocksCAD was fun and a pleasure. I especially like that it is based on OpenSCAD, which is what the Thingiverse Customizer uses!

The files for this Thing include 12 example snowflakes, and the BlocksCAD XML file.

Here's how to load this snowflake program into BlocksCAD and generate your own snowflakes.

  1. Download the Randomized Hex Snowflake.xml file.

  2. Open the BlocksCAD Editor

  3. Project -> Load Blocks from your Computer to load/import the XML file

  4. Click the Render button until you see a snowflake you like, then click the Generate STL button to download it!

Thank you! And enjoy! :)

remixed_from.title: GASB One - RC Flying wing fully printed (ONLY 9 PIECES GLUELESS)

description.text:
An even longer nose section with a small LERX where it meets the other wing sections, and it has flat sides and a pass-through hole intended for a rod which links to canards.

Right now it's a WIP as it likely needs some revision (interior bits), but I figure this much is a start. Based partially on the revised nose section, but manually remeshed since some things are easier in Blender when working with quads instead of tris. On top of all that might have to split the nose piece into two sections to make it easier to print.

I suppose this could be used to build a GASB-1.5? (Since it adds a GASB-2 feature with a part intended to fit the rest of the GASB-1.)

--- Edit ---
Added the file for a basic canard airfoil piece. Should be mirrored for the other side. Also keep in mind the hole is offset a bit towards the front. (Likely less stable if installed backwards.) I figure this size should be adequate for some good control authority (it's the moving plane type), however (as is the nature of this) you're free to try bigger or smaller ones.

--- Edit ---
New version of the main file. First version didn't have the little catches for the cover piece. This one should correct that.

title: E3D v6 Bowden X-Carriage with Sensor Holders: 10mm, 12mm, 18mm and BLTouch

description.text:
Update: Added version for the 12mm sensor.

Update: Added versions for a 10mm sensor and a BLTouch as well as parts design improvements.

This Bowden setup X-carriage mount is based on the one designed by Tech2C which many people is using. Designed from zero, I added a holder for an 18mm probe and I also reduced the gap from the base of the carriage to the hotend, as I always had the impression it was way too large.

I designed the part on Onshape and all the files are free to use and remix. You can either use the .step files available here or work directly on Onshape.com (an account is free as long as all your designs are public). I designed the parts using variables for every single measurement so that it can be easily customizable.

Once printed and installed the offsets for the Marlin Firmware are:

18mm Version
X offset= 34 mm (actual 33.60mm)
Y offset= 11 (actual 10.40mm)
Z offset must be calculated for every installation

12mm Version
X offset= 33 mm (actual 32.60mm)
Y offset= 18 (actual 17.50mm)
Z offset must be calculated for every installation

10mm Version
X offset= 32 mm (actual 31.60mm)
Y offset= 14 (actual 13.90mm)
Z offset must be calculated for every installation

BLTouch Version
X offset= 29 mm (actual 28.50mm)
Y offset= 12 (actual 12.00mm)
Z offset must be calculated for every installation

Original X-Carriage from Tech2C:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706

Hotend Fan Duct with Filament Chiller:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1746358

Onshape Link:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/279d254aed95fd192a65a7b4/w/bf9e23bbc5f31cf2b447b9c7/e/3637e63419dfeda4f942865b

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

65%

Notes:

Obviously this part cannot be printed with PLA.
I used PTEG and works very well, no deformation whatsoever.
ABS should also be OK (but I don't print on ABS).

I used a preset I have for printer parts which has a 65% infill by default to get stronger parts. I guess it could be tunned down.

Printed without supports nor rafts.

Assembly

I suggest adding the M4 nuts before fixing the fan duct if you are using the same I use, because otherwise, it will be a tricky thing to do afterward.

Some of the screw holes have been closed with a single-layer-thick sealing in order to make it easier to print without supports. After printing use a 4mm drill bit to open them up.

title: Power Supply Cover for Zonestar P802QR2

description.text:
March 3 2018 update, Thank you for the tips, they are much appreciated. I just wanted to say if any of you have the smaller version of the power supply on this printer and you have a way to take precise measurements (like a decent pair of calipers for example) please let me know. I'd like to make another version of this cover that actually fits on your printers without leaving a 10mm gap.

Power Supply Cover for the Zonestar P802QR2 Dual Extruder 3D Printer. This is pretty much a necessity for this printer. There may be other Covers that will fit, but I made this one specifically for the P802QR2.

Check out my Build and first impressions video where I talk about why this is necessary here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G4QIKGoLYi0
Also I made a review video for this printer earlier:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgiKoifPrPI

Print with the first layer height as 0.2mm so that you'll get the cool squares bridging effect on the bottom like you see on several of the parts on the Prusa i3 MK2S

Edit: 12/30/17 @ 5:54 PM CST - I updated the stl file because the hole for the plug/switch was causing problems with trying to plug in the power cord.

Edit: 12/31/17 @ 10:26 AM CST - I updated to two different stl files. one version has a hole that should allow you to route the z axis stepper motor wire through the Power supply cover, and the other version has a big enough recess so you should be able to slide the power supply cover into place after you've plugged in the stepper motor without having to bend the wires. Note, I haven't tried printing either of these yet, but they should both work fine.

comments.text: Thanks dfmsguitar for the power supply cover, I was searching something similar for Zonestar M8R2. I sliced the downloaded stl file and tried to print the gcode on Zonestar M8R2 but extruder stepper doesn't work at all. Am I missing something during slicing? In gcode I can spot some commands not supported by Repetier, e.g. M101 I replaced that with T0, but no result. Any help or guidance are welcome :-)

Check out our Etsy for all of our 3D printed awesomeness!
https://www.etsy.com/shop/CarryTheWhat This is the fully functional solder-free version of the snap-together mini lamp. Besides a 3D printer, all you need is some LEDs and some conductive thread like this: http://members.shaw.ca/ubik/thread/order.html It's a work in progress because there are still some kinks to work out, and I'm not sure what LEDs I want to use yet. I used v0.2 of the 3D-PCB library, which has tolerances calibrated for the Makerbot Replicator. The "bulb" of this lamp is an array that can hold 6 LEDs, and it snaps into the peg that holds the lamp shade on. Some of the arm pieces have an added peg so that the conductive thread can run down the arm to the base (on each side) without overlapping. The base has been adapted to accommodate 2xAAA batteries and a toggle switch. This model was made in blender, using the 3D-PCB openscad exports.

Print one of each file, with the exception of the 'peg caps' (print lots of these). The lamp is assembled much like the snap-together version -- assemble the arm in the same way. Once the arm is together, insert the LEDs into the bulb. It is a 2x3 array, with pairs of holes. When inserting an LED, make sure you insert the positive lead (the longer one) into the hole on the inside. This way, all the positive leads will emerge together in the center, and the negative leads will emerge together on the sides. Once you've inserted the LEDs you want, bend the excess into the peg slots nearby. tweezers are helpful to get a good bend. Next, cut two long lengths of conductive thread -- a few feet should give you plenty of leeway for wrapping. Detailed instructions for how to wrap can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Circuit-Boards-for-solder-free-printab/step3/Wrap-it-up/ Positive first: wrap up the positive peg on the top of the bulb, and insert a cap. Then wrap the negative pegs together to the remaining peg -- insert the peg caps to ensure a good hold. Thread the two threads out of the bulb towards the arm. In my prototype, I ran the positive out through the hole that snaps the arm to the shade, and the negative out the hole at the top of the shade -- but it doesn't really matter as long as it's not the same hole.. Do this while you insert the lamp shade and then snap the bulb into place. There are then three sets of pegs down the arm structure. When you wrap your way down, make sure to flex the arm structure in many directions to make sure you leave enough slack to allow for a wide range of motion. When you reach the bottom of the arm, attach it to the base. Wrap the excess threads to their respective battery terminals, again leaving enough slack for the range of motion you want. Cut two more lengths of thread, about 12 inches should be sufficient. Run one from one battery terminal across the switch. Tie a knot in the toggle, and run it to the other battery terminal. Again, for detailed instructions, see the instructables. And you're done! EDIT One of the pegs, going from the arm through the shade into the bulb, is originally printed at an upwards orientation, causing it to be prone to snapping. I have uploaded a modified version so it can be printed on it's side.

description.text:
I will be working on a direct drive version of this in the coming weeks, as I know the cross over belts setup can be touchy. I am working on fully redesigning the TwoUp as a Utilimaker like design. Greatly increasing the build volume from 175x175x125mm (100x100x125mm for OneUp) to Y250 x X220 x Z200-230mm (if using the longer X and Y rods). The Z is a range only because it can depend on the extruder being used. The 230 would be for the E3D V6 hot end.
Note: This update can be done for the OneUp if your OneUp is reaching the 100x100x125 build area. the largest printed part should now fit in the build area.
The design will utilize these Existing Components:
(4) LM8LUU Bearings
(1) R1038-2RS Ball Bearing
(3) R6-2RS Ball Bearings
(4) Stepper Motors
(1) AnUbis Hot End assembly w/ Thermistor
(1) 3/8"-12 Acme Lead Screw Nut
(1) Printrboard
(1) 12V x 40mm Fan
(1) Power supply
(1) Brass Feeder Nut
(1) Extruder Tension Spring
Purchase Parts (these quantities include the reused parts):
(1) HAUHA8-4040E-W400-D400-H400 Aluminum Extrusion Kit MISUMI
(4) 8mm x 350mm Linear Rods
(2) 1602ZZ Bearing
(1) R1038-2RS Ball Bearing - Required for only one of the Extruder Options
(6) R6-2RS Bearings
(2) GT2 Belt @ 2000mm - Open
(6) #10-24 - 1 1/4" Flat Head Machine Screw
(12) #10-24 Hex Nut
(1) 1/4-20 x 1/2 Machine Screw - Required for only one of the Extruder Options
(12) 1/4-20 x 3/4" Machine Screw/Bolt
(2) 1/4-20 x 1" Counter Sunk Screw
(12) 1/4-20 Jam Nuts
(2) 1/4-20 Hex Nut (3) 3/8"-12 Acme Lead Screw Nuts
(29) M3x16 Machine Screws
(1) M3x25 Machine Screw
(4) M3x30 Cap Screws
(2) M3x50 Machine Screws
(2) M3x60 Machine Screws
(21) M3 Hex Nuts
(8) M4x16 Counter Sunk Machine Screws
(4) M4x30 Machine Screws
(4) M4 Hex Nuts
(8) GT2 Pulley 20Teeth 5mm Bore
(3) 3/8"-12 ACME threaded Rod @ 13" to 13 1/2" long
(1) 1/4" x 16" x 20" Aluminum/Plexiglass/Glass Sheet
(1) .090" to 1/8" x 12" x 12" Aluminum Sheet
(10-12) .36 x .042 x .69 free length Compression Springs
(1) Extruder Tension Spring (the spring from a standard Retractable Gel Pen may work)
Optional - (2) SCS8UU - Pillow Block Linear Bearing (May be used for the Gantry slide Blocks to replace two of the LM8LUU bearings I noted as reused from the OneUp/TwoUp. Note if the Pillow blocks are used you will need (8) additional M4x16 Machine Screws to attach the pillow block to the Gantry Blocks.
.
Uploaded the Bowden I'm going to possibly use.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310239
.
Uploaded the Direct Drive Version
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529455
.
Note they are a remix of StephanBuger's from his gantry redesign. Its uses all his part except the back cover which has been modified
.
Uploaded an Azteeg X3 Controler Box as well
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:521187
.
11/12/15
Found a minor issue on the Appendix in my instructions. One of the dimensions showed to the wrong point after printing. I had to select it and move it to get it to render properly. It should now be correct.
.
11/9/15
So I've been trying to print a few calibration cubes but I'm currently running into an issue with the belt slipping on one of the pulleys for the X and Y axis causing an occasional shift diagonally across the bed. I'm going to reprint the gear plates as the version I'm using isn't the most current version on here so it doesn't have the counter boar for the nuts to sit in. This should stop the screws from slanting which I believe is causing the slipping I'm experiencing. other than that all movements are working well. I did see what looked like the bed wobbling while raising from all the way down to building position. I may need to put a guide or something at the motor as I believe the flexible coupler (since it only has two screws in it at 90 deg's) isn't sitting centered which is almost forcing the threaded rod to wobble as it turns (If someone knows of a way to correct wobble from a flexible coupler please comment in the comments so I can attempt a quick fix instead of adding/modifying parts). Once I get the slipping issue corrected I'll try printing a tall print and see what it does. I have an idea on how to correct the wobble but it will mean that 2-4 rods and linear bearings would be needed to counteract. I may be able to reuse the LM8LUU bearings but the rods from the OneUp may not work. The TwoUp has four 8mm x 290mm rods that aren't being used currently in this deisgn that could be reused while the OneUp only has two 8mm x 290mm rods that I may be able to reuse. I fear I may need four rods to correct and the remaining OnUp rods are only 200mm which if I add them will reduce the new build height of this printer. No matter a second pair of LM8LUU bearings would be needed for this fix but I may reduce them to just LM8UU bearings as these are smaller and you can order them from amazon (12 for $13.00).
.
11/2/15
I updated the parts list as well as added the PDF for the assembly instructions. I've gotten everything to move and work (mostly). I have not made any prints worth showing. Will tighten down the settings and possibly upload the firmware here. There is always room for improvement so feel free to note any changes you've done that might improve on the design.
.
4/25/16
Been playing with the Bowden setup and found that without the direct drive plate with the small piece of ptfe tubing for the E3D V6 hot end, the hot end itself tended to wiggle back and forth causing some error in the prints. I designed a plate that will need to be attached through the holes the direct drive would have attached through that has two M3x40 screws and 2 M3 Hex nuts that press down on the top of the hot end enough to secure it from wiggleing. I recommend finding some aluminum screws if you use the E3D hot ends (or E3D clones) to prevent from damaging the Aluminum they are made from. I have updated the instructions with this change. Added to the Part list pages and to Page 10 showing the Bowden Plate. I also added the Anubis filament guide to the downloadable files. I noticed it never attached. Be aware I haven't tested this Anubis guide so it may have issues that I'm not aware of. Use at your own risk

Most parts are defaulting in the Wrong plane. I will attempt to correct them before I move the project off work-in-progress The instructions are in the PDF labeled as: OneUp-TwoUp Full Redesign Instructions.pdf Note: this document may change as I perfect the bugs. It may also call out information that isn't available as of yet (such as the updated Threaded Rod Bearing Bracket. Use these only as reference until I release this Thing from the Work In Progress state

comments.text: Stock extruder or the one referenced for this redesign? The best way to see if the stock extruder is feeding filament properly would be to mark the filament about 100mm away from the extruder. The mark should be from a known point (say a mark on your desk). Manually turn the extruder on and Feed 20mm of filament using repetier. Then measure to see if the filament actually moved the 20mm. If it didn't then you need to adjust the feed rate in the EEPROMS setting.

comments.text: you may want to check out the design from Shapeoko 2 which is actually a CNC open design from Inventables or Gigabot from Re3D. Both these uses the same concept of the design. Not too sure if your design has dual motor on the y axis to move the gantry back and forth. The design that the 2 system uses is for the controller board to simultaneously move the 2 motors that directly drives the gantry motion. Each one of the belts are only running parallel to the direction of the gantry movement without the need to go 90 degrees. I am using a makerbot 2X also uses the same method of the setup except that the motor is only on one side while the other side is just the rod and carrier.
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: Those designs are using an H-Bot design. There is actually a flaw with the H-bot design in that it uses one belt that actually has the ability to "torque" the frame cause prints that are requiring precision to fall out of spec. While it can be pretty accurate, the problem is the way the belt is tensions that basically makes the frame of the machine try and twist. The CoreXY belt system that I designed is the improved system that started with the H-Bot and corrected this issue. The cross over is required. The most I'll have to do, is if I see the point where the belts cross over, start to rub, I can raise one side slightly at the gear brackets to compensate.

description.text: This is a dual board case for standard-ish MOSFET boards. It's designed (but not certified) to provide IP20 protection to any parts that may carry relatively high current or voltage. Which is to say, substantially reduce the chances of short-circuits, and other kinds of accident vs. bare boards, or open shell cases. With the (random ebay) boards I use, they heat sinks are barely warm to the touch, so there's no provision for active cooling. It's a little unfinished, but the prototype worked fine.
The bolts are M3, 30mm long, with dome nuts. Eight is clearly overkill, but I designed it first as a pair of single cases and fused them together, and stopped when the prototype worked fine.
Just some universal filament clip, should work on any spool

remixed_from.author: Zeppelinum
remixed_from.title: Cooling Fan Duct for E3D All Metal Hot End V6

title: 40mm version - Cooling Fan Duct for E3D v6 (DiiiCooler Compatible)

description.text:
This part is a remix of the "e3d-duct-small.stl" part from the Cooling Fan Duct for E3D All Metal Hot End V6 by Zeppelinum, which is a bracket you can use to mount this DiiiCooler remix onto your E3D hotend.

My version of the part allows you to mount a 40mm fan instead of a 30mm fan for hotend cooling. I wanted to mount a quieter 40mm Noctua fan, but found no part on Thingiverse that would fit. Since the original model contains no source, I had to modify it in Blender. The bottom of the fan duct is nearly horizontal instead of tapered to avoid hitting your DiiiCooler.

Hardware
The holes should be big enough to fit M3 nuts with short M3 screws to mount your fan. A 40mm Noctua FLX fan comes with these rubbery mounting screws you can just pull through, which you can also use instead.

Printing

  • Orientation: Print horizontal, as it imports by default in Cura. (Print it in same orientation as you're going to mount it. The layer lines need to be along the long axis of the model so the arms can flex as you mount it on your hotend.)
  • Layer lines / Infill: I used a 0.2mm layer height with 15% infill and 3 wall shells. The model is so dense that it's going to end up being nearly 100% infill in practice if you stick with 3 wall shells and a 0.4mm nozzle.
  • Supports: Use them!
  • Material: I used eSun PLA+. Seems to be working fine, no deformation. Regular PLA should work too.

title: adding prescription lens to Eachine EV100 goggles

description.text:
I wanted to add prescription lens to my Eachine EV100 Goggles
I have printed this cutting maker
I took an old PLASTIC prescription lens with a close diopter to my current prescription.

I have found the estimated center of the lens and marked it with a marker. then I draw on the lens the cutting border with the 3d part.

after that, I have used a grinder to grind the lens to the marked borders.

After washing the lens from the plastic dast ' i have pushed the lenses to the goggles, and fine-tune the diopters with the EV100 diopter tuner

this is work with plastic lenses
lens size is :

26X17.5 mm with 2 mm radius

This is pressure fit to your bl-touch to keep the probe pin clean and to keep strings and webbing from getting into the path way the probe pin moves in
Alot of people start to have issues with their probe sticking, not deploying and just becoming unreliable
Every one of these i've seen was because the probe pin or the path way of the probe pin had stringing/webing in it. Alot of times you can just barely see it at all.

This should keep that from happening as well as possible protect the probe pin itself

Just align the pin with the hole and press on
tolerances are tight so if your printer is not well calibrated you may need to open the hole a little I only gave 1.5mm of room for the pin to help keep anything out

As always I accept tips

title: Survival Still (Water)

description.text:
Solar water still that uses two soda (Coke) bottles and a 6mm tube and hose, The bottom bottle needs to be painted black and filled with the grey (dirty) water, the top clear bottle will act as a condensation chamber that collects the clean water and releases it down the tube and out of the hose into your collection container, its easier to understand in the pictures
This was inspired by a great friend and designer: https://www.thingiverse.com/WarHawk8080/about Thanks buddy for the great Idea, you always come up with the coolest ones.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GF9yYGwPcNw

!Don't forget to CHECK OUT my other designs and FOLLOW my daily KooKoo uploads, Enjoy ;)

comments.text: Doesn't need it (it's a solar still). (The principle) Bad water goes in bottom bottle (painted black or darkened)  top bottle  is clear, bottom bottle heats up the water in the sun, due to natural evaporation pure water vapor rises, clean water condenses in the upper bottle walls and trickles down, is captured in the catch lip and is syphoned off on the discharge tube for collection and consumption.

The original brush is great bot very heavy.

Standard conical brushes uses conical fitting.

Happy cleaning!

Thanks to Tyson and Makita for there great products!

author: cadshef

title: Big Ben hands for Real Tower Clock

description.text:
Clock hands for Real Tower Clock. This is part of tower clock project - see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2739252
I enclosed Fusion 360 files so size can be changed to adjust to clock diameter. Also two small test hands are included for testing tower clockwork. With the mounting block the whole clock can be connected easily to the wall/clock hole.

1.

Printing the hands: two parts for minute and one for hour. On CR-10 printer the hours fits perfect on whole bed at 45 degrees orientation.

2.

use 2 M3 nuts+screws for connection minute hand. It should be rock solid now.

3.

use small lead weight balls from diving to fill up weight container and slide two of them carefully in slots on minute axis. These are needed to balance the minute hand. In orginal size it weights about 200g with this addional weight included.

4.

the hour hand will be just put on clockwork hour axis after set it to 12 position via software or manually (12 position = same as optical stop pointing upwards inside optical sensor).

5.

the minute hand needs two additonal M3 screws+nuts to mount it on minute axis. Also point it upards to 12 position with same position of minute axis.

5. clock-face

The clock-face can be easily printed by company on alu-dibond material with laser cut included for circle and inner 3cmx3cm square. Please tell company to laser cut (or similar) that square as well.
I used service from here: http://www.vis24.de/product.php/121/117/direktdruck-auf-alu-dibond

  • 910x910mm … this might be different size for your project
  • 3mm
  • “Konturfräsung” (contour cut)
  • data check (PDF)
    and costs me around 120 EUR inc. delivery.
    Also you might want to have different clock face or hands. It should be no problem to design this yourself.
    As I wanted Big Ben clock face I bought image in EPS format here for perfect quality:
    https://de.123rf.com/search.php?word=big+ben+clock&srch_lang=de&imgtype=2&t_word=&t_lang=de&orderby=0&t_word=&t_lang=de&oriSearch=big+ben&mediapopup=3853382&sti=laqi6onjhixx16l6v7|
    costs around 12 EUR.
    Then I removed the hands from EPS file. I used Affinity Photo for this task and exported to PDF.

description.text:
Benchy organic:
My channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5vIeeKUhciotzxCg-0-TBw

I title the piece: "Green Tears of Envy" ... 
MakerBot a pair for each of your favorite girls ... 
This is another of many entries to the makezine.com/go/makerbot  contest ...
blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/04/makerbot_giveaway.html

MakerBot a few of these, buff them shiny and tint ... give them a try ... then send me a half-dozen please ... I'll buff 'n shine them.
If you successfully make this with a 3D printer please send me the build-file and machine type so it can be uploaded here for others to use.

So I liked the idea of JohnSL's spool holder, but I didn't have any M8 nuts and bolts lying about, so remixed it for use without nuts and bolts. Pretty snug depending on your calibration. You'll probably need to tidy things up a bit with a scalpel. Shouldn't need support. For one filament spool, print:
  • 2x spool_bearingholder.stl
  • 8x spool_bearinggrip.stl
    • Alternatively, just print:
    2x spool_bearingholder_full You'll need:
  • 4x 608 bearings.

Place the bearings lined up with the holes in the spool holder, then plug in one of the printed bearing grips through the holes on either side into each of the bearings. Then push these tightly together onto the bearings.  
Once all bearings are secure then you're good to go with one under each of the rims of your spool.

title: C525 Cam Holder for Tevo Tornado

description.text:
Remixed to work on Tevo Tornado.

2040 Rail Mount:
Has been designed to fit the rails on sides of Tevo Tornado and be very snug. takes a little to get on at first but holds great ad doesn't move unless you want it to. I printed mine with 100% infill for extra strength for adjustable arm.

35mm Extension:
print multiple copies to make adjustable arm as long as you want! I made 6 for mine to start with. Printed with 100% infill for strength. Be gentile when connecting them or you will crack the connection points. light sanding helps but not to much or it will make the connection to loose.

C525 Camera Mount:
The mount is designed to replace stock camera hinges. requires removing the 2 orange stickers on hinge side of the base to disassemble the hinge mechanism. There are 4 black screws and 1 silver screw holding the hinge mechanism. don't loose the silver screw you need that one for the new mount! Use that silver screw to attach the mount then just attach to adjustable arm. Printed with 100% infill for strength.

title: 3mm MDF Lot Basing for Structures and Buildings Wargaming
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A few left over bits from end of the year. I amalgamated a bunch of filler cuts from my own personal templates/cutting jobs that I intend to use as basing for village, building or other structural terrain. Easy enough for anyone to do but here are mine if you feel like taking a short cut? I present a variety of sizes for 4"x6" and 4"x4" up to 9"x10" (approximately). I'm quite sure you can readjust sizing in whatever app you're using if you use the included SVG file.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C) sheet, the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. Sheet has a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/bUJMYdGA35H

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are NOT needed if you don't enable tails or lips, in which case you can flip it top down in your slicer to print without supports.

description.text:
This is a customizable shower cubby tray to let soap bars drain, and to allow better ventilation behind shampoo bottles. To create your custom STL file for printing, edit the downloadable .scad file in OpenSCAD, or click the "Open in Customizer" link on this page to customize. If your cubby is larger than your printer's bed, you can print two or more parts to fit your cubby.

You can specify the width and depth of your shower cubby:

  • The depth does NOT include the radius of the rounded nose, so the actual tray will extend an additional height/2 beyond the depth you specify.
  • You can specify a depth that is approximately 15% more than the actual depth of your cubby and still have the front feet within the cubby. This will extend the shelf outward beyond the cubby's front edge, which might be useful to keep large shampoo bottles from sliding out to crash to your shower floor (as long as you don't extend it so far that you constantly bump the tray).

You can also adjust the height and thickness of each main "beam".

  • I find that a height of 10mm and a thickness of 2mm works well.
  • Note that height is of the main (front to back) beams only. Optional feet, tails, and lips (see below) will add to the overall tray height.

Finally, you can optionally add feet, a "tail", and a "lip" to your cubby tray.

  • Feet are enabled by default. They will raise the overall tray off the cubby floor by height/2 to aid in drainage and ventilation underneath the tray.
  • Tails are disabled by default. They are height/2 tall in the back. They help keep shampoo bottles slightly forward from the rear cubby wall to aid in ventilation, but you loose a little useable depth in the process.
  • Lips are disabled by default. They are height/4 tall on the front edge. They help keep shampoo bottles from slipping off the front edge and crashing to the floor, but you loose a little useable depth in the process.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Supports are NOT needed if you don't enable tails or lips, in which case you can flip it top down in your slicer to print without supports.

remixed_from.title: lm8uu snap in holder Y carriage for Prusa

title: LM8UU mount replacement for Monoprice MakerSelect v2.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Never understand why there's only 3 LM8UU bearing, instead of 4, on the Wanhao/MP MakerSelect 2.1 underneath the Y axis plate. Nevertheless, I want 4 bearings because I can see the 2 corners bend on the Y axis plate when I adjust those spring (the 2 corners where only 1 bearing on the Y axis rod)

Modify xnaron's holder for Wanhao/MP MakerSelect 2.1 Y plate. Working great so far for couple overnight print. Now all 4 corner is straight and leveled, don't need to spend extra money on a new Y plate and found bed leveling easier.

I re-use the existing M4 screws from the mount that came with the printer and it just fit, but if you have slightly (2~3mm) longer M4 screws that's even better. Just in case you wondered, I ran out of M4 nuts, that's why I only put 3 screws per mount in my photos.

NOTE
Please pay attention to the Y axis plate I have, if yours different then the screw holes may not line up.

description.text:
Dicengard is a shorter, chubbier, almost chibified version of Isengard - that's also a dice tower!

I would suggest having a fence or something to catch the dice when they leave the tower, they tend to come out at a pretty high rate of speed. Also, for the top and bottom half version, the pins are intended more for alignment than strength, you can choose to change the orientation or use something else as pins if you desire more strength at the join.

Both OBJ and STL versions of the files included, both in one complete object for larger printers, and two halves for smaller printers.

author: Lollixx

description.text:
G Scale trackside equipment box to hide DCC electronic equipment. It is designed to hold a DS2 two turnout decoder, and an AR1 automatic reverse controller for track loops.

I printed out the shell in one shebang, but I included the .STL files for the walls and corners in case somebody couldn't get it to print in one piece.

The roof gets glued to the shell (I used hot glue), and that assembly simply slides over the base to cover and protect the electronic boards.

I drilled out the handle holes and bent a 0.047" piano wire to make the handles and sealed them in from the back with hot glue.

It should be somewhat rain resistant if you seal the roof to the shell, and seal the wire access hole in the bottom after running the wires.

print_settings.Notes:: Print time is roughly 30 minutes.

description.text:
This is a test model for 3D printers.
Our object is to print 2 wheels, meet them together, and rotate them smoothly, like below.
https://youtu.be/KiCR8q_Z9a8

There are 3 points to be tested in this model.

  1. How your print lines are clean (well retracted and well restarted).
    A circle should be closed well, and should not be bridged to next circle.
    If the circles are not clean enough, you can not meet them.

  2. No back rush.
    Back rush or vibration of timming belt leads distortion on the circles,
    then you can not rotate them, if you cleared point 1.

  3. Symmetry of X Y axes.
    If your 3D Printer does not have enough symmetry or right angle in X Y axes,
    it leads distortion on the circles, then you can not rotate them, if you cleared point 1. and 2.
    It is not matter on cartesian printers, but sometimes problem on delta printers.

Printer:

m200 (hand made)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24*0.12mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I am using 3DXTech's CFR-PETG filament and ø0.20mm stainless nozzle,
0.6mm retraction, layers of 5 for top, 4 for bottom, 3 for shell, 10 skirt,
260C degrees head temprature, no bed heater, no filament cooler, 1600mm/min print speed,
80% at outlines, 15mm/sec jerk, 1600mm/sec2 acceleration.

Print time is roughly 30 minutes.
Holds a pair of 605zz (5x14x5mm) bearings using 20mm M5 screw as an axel.

D-Bot CoreXY

title: 28 mm warhammer scale - rivers pieces with base, bridge and pier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello,

Here are some frames for tabletop rivers. Why frames? The need painting, flocking, water effects etc.. There are in 28 mm scale. There 8 different pieces + 1 corner piece that can be fit in either way. So you can build your own river. Pieces can bij glued on hardboard, carton or on the base water file that can be printed.
There is also a bridge that can be build with a handrail. You will need the handrail support file about 8-10 times and the handrail 2 times. The little one is a pier that also need 2 support files.

Everything you need is in de downloads, just ask if there are any problems.
Happy printing
Frederique

author: LewisPat3D

title: Electronic box for Real Tower Clock

description.text:
Electronics for Real Tower Clock. This is part of tower clock project - see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2739252

I enclosed Fusion 360 files. This electronic box consists of the following parts:

  • Arduino
  • two stepper motor drivers on the left
  • two power distribution breadboards
  • connection slots for DCF module
  • holes for wires for stepper motors and optical sensors to clockwork.
  • two screw holes for connection the electronic box on top of clockwork.

For whole assembly no soldering is needed. For parts list check main project page. Short breadboard cables (10cm) are used.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

1.

slide in the two small parts of the breadboard into the position and connect 5V to the left and 3V to the right power bar. Mount Arduino board with small printed pins.

2.

slide in stepper motor driver boards with wires connected

3.

connect stepper motors to Pins to Arduino and 5V power bar
Pins 10-13 for minute stepper and Pins 6-9 for hour stepper.

4.

if you have plastic clock-face you can directly mount DCF module by sliding in to the box. Otherwise use long wires and put it near a window to get proper signal. I am using alu dibond clock face which blocks all signals so I had to do it this way. You find instructions about how to get DCF module running here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738964

5.

Screw top plate of clockwork at electronic box. One stepper motor driver board might have to be removed temporary for better reaching the screw.

6.

connect optical switch to Arduino and stepper motors to stepper motor driver boards.
The hour optical switch uses pin 5 and for minute pin 4.
here you see all wiring of a prototype version.

7. finished… go to main project page for testing clockwork with Arduino sketch:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2739252

description.text:
Please note The original "diffuser" component file had a scaling issue, has been replaced with "diffuserB" which should scale properly. The diffuser should be 15mm in diameter.

My Moon Globe is a compilation of the best parts of the following merged in a way that makes it unique and I hope a little more user friendly. In addition, my build uses a LED module with remote control for colour choice brightness and fade effects. https://www.ebay.ca/itm/232434506112 Circuit Board USB Remote Control 16-Color DIY 3D Printing Moon Light Night TE783 or similar. I have added a diffuser cap for the LED module to scatter the light a bit more evenly for I think better effect. You may need, to lightly scrape parts for better fit for final assembly. The light module slides into the base/cap holder at the center gently turn for snug fit once in place. The base cap threads nicely into the globe threaded collar it allows disassembly to service light module if need be. Connect the battery lead, charge the module. You can turn it on by touching the metal collar of the charge port or better use the convenient IR remote set on base of your choice and enjoy the fruits of the work.

I used the moon globe and base from this post amended to incorporate the items mentioned from the previous two posts.

The components were redesigned by extracting the features from the sources that I felt were desirable in a final lamp. I wanted to design a cap/base that threaded together with the globe itself requiring no gluing and easily disassembled for repair/servicing if need be. Further, I wanted a mount compatible with the lamp module that I was planning on using that would that would allow it to snap into place with no hardware required. This was accomplished with 3D Builder. Final components were merged into single parts which were further refined in MeshMixer to blend textures better at the joints.

title: Flex Owl 130 v2 flexible indestructible safe quad

description.text:
UPDATE 2018-02-08: Frame updated. Read below.

My second flexible quad creation inspired by original FlexRC's OWL quad. There is a similarity in the quad name, mine "flex" refers to flexible ;)

As my first Flex Quad 130, also this is designed indestructibility in mind. Also the safety of surroundings as a second point.

This frame is designed to be printed in semiflexible 98A filament like Fillamentum's Flexfill.

Update 2018-02-08: In previous version, standoffs were too close to the props. In fast turns frame bends a little and cause propellers to touch standoffs. In this new version added more space between props and standoffs. In top frame there is hollows for FC screws to be away from touching the battery.
Also added two version of top frame: with and without battery grip. The battery grip should be printed in very flexible TPU like 85A or softer. You can print directly on to the top frame using two separate printing process or print the battery grip separately and glue it on the frame.

See parts I used in this quad on Rotorbuilds. As a battery I use 850mAh 4S for agile and 1800mAh 3S for cruising.

Please, refer your creations to me here or [email protected] or [email protected] :)

author: DiAleksi

description.text:
Like Netsquash in the source of this model, I had problems using the original adjustable bed clamp due to the very small tolerances allowed with the printer.

I also had a problem with Netsquash's version with the well where the screw connects to the printer extrusion. It normally spins freely to bring the nut in the extrusion up against the plastic and metal. Unfortunately the well wasn't wide enough and the screw was cutting into the well making it nearly impossible to tighten it appropriately to the extrusion.

This is a modified version where I've expanded the screw well to 9mm and raised it up a few mm to ensure a good strong fit to the extrusion. This is currently working great on my Anycubic Kossel delta.

I've also included the fusion 360 and .step file for anyone else that wants to mod this further.

A simple snowflake created using the 3D modelling software BlocksCAD.

#BlocksCADSnowflake

This is for a Skyviper 2450 GPS model quadcopter drone.

It is very small gear. I had to use a .15mm nozzle on my SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V3. The slic3r settings is for MatterHackers PRO PETG. Which is what I had loaded in the printer at the time I needed this. I have no issues with it.

I have included 2 Sketchup files as well. The "Complete" file is the gear I printed. The "No Hole" version does not have the hole. Since you will most likely need to play with that part of the file to get it to press fit on your motor shaft. The shaft is 1mm (.5mm radius). But, printing with my printer and settings and shrinkage I had to make the hole 1.5mm (.75 radius) thick.

If you want to modify the shaft hole just open the "No Hole" file in Sketchup then:

  1. Using the Circle tool click in the center of the gear and type .5. This will make a 1mm size hole (this is the number you will need to change to get to work with your printer and slicer settings. Make sure it press fits onto the shaft very snug. I had to increase mine to .75 to fit my shaft perfect).
  2. Using the Pointer tool. Right click inside the circle you just created and select Erase.
  3. Using the Push/Pull tool. click on the gear and type in 4. This will grow the gear to 4mm thick.
  4. Export to stl and slice and print.
  5. Undo everything you just did and repeat until you get the inside hole of the gear perfect. It should be very snug but you shouldn't need to hammer it on.

description.text:
These are the brackets and mounts I created to convert my instep bike trailer into a cross country ski child carrier. The skis are 110cm youth Cross Country skis. The tow poles are made from EMT conduit. I have included the Left and Right brackets and the mount (mount is the same for both sides) as well as an optional mount template to aid in marking the hole locations on the skis for drilling. The mounts are attached in a similar fashion to a regular cross country ski mount. Plenty of youtube videos to help you there.

Although I feel comfortable towing my child in this trailer, I am not suggesting it is safe for you to tow your child with this. I thoroughly inspect each part before and after use to make sure there are no problems. So far I have used this trailer 3 times. I have put at least 15 miles on them. No issues thus far. My bike trailer is only rated to carry 80 lbs. I have no idea what the capacity of my ski kit is. My child weighs about 28lbs.

1/31/18

I have used this ski trailer setup now about a dozen times this winter and I estimate that I have put about 60 miles on it. Everything is holding up well! It's great to be able to ski with my little one.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

75

Notes:

I Printed the mounts and brackets in PLA with a 4 mm wall thickness for added strength. I recommend a minimum fill thickness of 50%

I have a print bed area of 220 x 220 mm. You likely need a print bed of this size in order to print these brackets.

Assembly:

The mounts are attached to the ski using 8 10-12 x 1/2" screws per ski. Leg brackets attach to mounts using 2 3/8" bolts 2" in length. Brackets attach to trailer using a 1/2" bolt. I placed a washer between the frame of the trailer and the bracket and installed the bolt loose enough to allow the skis to pivot freely. Use nylock nuts to keep things from coming loose. The brackets and mounts are recessed for 3/8' washers that are 1" in diameter. I used the same washers for the top, but drilled out the center to 1/2"

I used 3/4" EMT conduit for the tow poles.
Designed in tinkercad

The slug is meant to be glued to the bottom of the platform top.  
Currently the guns also need to be glued to the platform top but magnets could be used as well.  
UPDATE: I updated the cannons themselves to be 10% bigger and I made the tubes underneath a little thicker. They print out really well now.

title: Tiny Commodore C64C, dual head keyboard letter print etc.

description.text:
I thought I'd 3D print the keyboard letters of RabbitEngineerings "Mini Commodore C-64c".
But I couldn't stop there of course.
I made a little clip about it:
https://youtu.be/q_a_4oVy28Y

  • I made the keys beveled, which made them look better, but made the printing area even smaller.
  • I added more authentic details to the C64C, way to many details.
  • Tightened up the, in my opinion, loose fit a bit.
  • I made the floppy disc reader locking latch movable.
  • I made floppy discs, many floppy discs, which fit in the reader, and have moving discs inside them. They even got that little index hole.
  • I made a printed screen for the monitor, which displays its contents when you turn the monitor on. Yes, there's light in the box now....

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed everything at 0.1 mm with a 0.35 mm nozzle.
My printer had a bad day, (needs a little service), but don't expect to print these items without some effort.

  • The monitor has support added to it's design. It's a minimal support only, but in my opinion, it's enough.
  • The pin of the floppy disc reader latch has to be cut to about 5 mm. It's printed lenght is out of technical printing reasons.
  • The floppys are designed to be printed with 0.1 mm at all layers, including the very first layer. You might be able to do it with 0.2 in the first layer

• Preferably remove the supports from the monitor with a top quality side cutter.
  • The light in the monitor can be made out of those cheap battery operated tealights. You have to cut some corners of the base, but it's easily made. For a better result, sand the LED dim.
  • The floppy halves need to be glued togheter. Use a little PVA glue at the corners.

title: Real Tower Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Real tower clock… yes this is the real thing: a tower clock with hands in original size and used at a real castle already! This clockwork costs less 160 EUR for clockwork, electronics/motors, clock face and hands all together and around 40 EUR without clock face. The clock runs always in time (automatically adjust for summer/winter time). I provided all Fusion 360 files so it can be changed to different sizes or clock faces. Also full software+parts list is included and no soldering is needed for this project! Anyway this should not be made by beginner but you do not need to be an expert in electronics as well I would say it is similar easy/difficult as building up a 3D printer from a kit. You also should know about how to get Arduinio sketches running. Also this clock runs on its own just needs power supply.
This project is devided in several parts:

  1. Big Ben hands for Real Tower Clock and clock face: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738980
  2. Electronics: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2739153
  3. DCF 77 module for precise time signal (see FAQ below): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738964
  4. and clockwork here on this page

Many use cases are possible:

  • filling up clock hole - like in my house
  • small churches who have not much money for tower clock
  • at home for wall decoration
  • because of the low price you could design different clock faces and hands and change the whole appearance of clock anytime you want

The main reason in my situation was to have a lightweight clock which can be removed and which supports long/heavy hands.
On the market you can buy only huge metal clockworks which costs around 10 times of this one or cheap quartz clockworks which are not able to move bigger clock hands (so mostly these are fake/smaller ones in home decoration clockworks). I did not want to lose this view:

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

See FAQ below before you start. parts list:

  • DCF receiver: https://www.pollin.de/p/dcf-empfangsmodul-dcf1-810054
    5,45 EUR

  • optical end stop switch
    http://r.ebay.com/gSkSjc
    1 EUR each

  • Arduino: around 5-6 EUR

  • 1 Mini 400 Contacts Breadboard
    https://www.ebay.de/itm/322750147657
    1 EUR

  • pack of 10cm breadboard cable, female to male.
    important: 20cm I do not recommend, 10cm is much better for this project here.
    http://r.ebay.com/sWRflC
    1,2 EUR

  • 5V Stepper Motor 28BYJ-48+Drive Test Module Board
    http://r.ebay.com/pi64Gf
    1,68 EUR each. Do not buy the ones with blue circuit board because it will not fit in slots inside case.

  • USB power supply

  • two of 5x11x4mm ball bearings
    (5mm inner diameter, 11 mm outer diameter)
    http://r.ebay.com/JUnSyT
    10 pcs … 2 EUR

  • two ball bearings 15x32x9
    (15 inner diameter, 32 outer diameter)
    http://r.ebay.com/cfyGsE
    2,36 EUR for 2 pcs

  • 10 cm metal rod, 5mm diameter (M5)
    e.g. get a longer threaded rod and cut it shorter: https://www.amazon.de/dp/B01M0IWY22/ref=cm_sw_em_r_mt_dp_U_7XMqAbB41ER0P
    or here you can get in 10cm size 5pcs for 3,24 EUR: http://r.ebay.com/MKXWeU

  • a bunch of M3 screws, different length with hex socket. I recommend this set:
    https://www.banggood.com/240pcs-M3-DIN912-Hex-Socket-Head-Cap-Screw-Nut-Assorted-Kits-4-25mm-p-1074609.html?rmmds=myorder&cur_warehouse=CN
    it is 7,69 EUR

  • 100g lead weight in small balls like this one for diving purpose
    https://www.amazon.de/OMS-Soft-Blei-5kg-5Kg/dp/B011S3WI5C/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1514303398&sr=8-2&keywords=softblei&th=1&psc=1
    costs 10 EUR for 500g and you need around 100g
Instructions

1.

rint all parts and on photo you see the clockwork case:

It has got mounting elements for ball bearings of hour axis, stepper motors and clock face here a photo of earlier version without walls:

It also uses embedded nuts for top plate screws and some mounts. Clean these slots and remove some filament left after printing otherwise the nut will not fit.

2.

mount optical stop at minute gear. You need a little force to get it with a “click” on it. Also you should place nut inside the slot for axis. On second photo you see it with metal rod/lead screw for minute axis.

3.

assemble both axis. It is not very difficult: first you have to put the small ball bearings inside the hour axis tube on both sides (not shown on photos but it is very easy). Put one of the bigger gear on that axis, the hour gear and hour optical stop like on photo. Both bigger ball gears can be moved by some force and the first one should be at end of axis and second one has to be adjusted by placing it in gear mounts from case. In photo you also see test hour hand placed on hour axis.

4.

mount optical sensors at ball bearings top with nuts and M3 screws. Now find the correct placement of optical stops. The big
ball bearings might have to be moved a bit. On photo you see a perfect placement.

After assembled both optical stops, sensors and ball bearing tops you should test if you can rotate 360 degrees both axis very easily by hand. It is very important that optical stop does not block full 360 degrees rotation.

5.

mount stepper motors and gears. And on photo you see nearly full assembly just the right gear is still loose and not mounted on stepper axis.
At this step it is important that both optical stops points at top. So you have full access to gear mount screw at top every time you go to this position.

6.

build up electronics as described here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2739153

7.

test if clockwork motors work by “Tower_Clock_move_motor” Arduino sketch. This one should just move one stepper motor and you can switch to another one by changing the constant “move_minute” to “false”.

8.

now start Tower_Clock sketch it is main program to get it running. Check on “Serial Monitor” output for startup sequence:

If something does not work check connection of wires. So for instance if there is a DCF signal error DCF module might not be plugged in.
After DCF signal it moves both hands - one after another - to top/12h position and should stop. Receiving the time signal needs several minutes and if it gets the time it should run as expected.

9.

If clockwork works with test hands you should print out long ones (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738980
) and assemble it at axis.

10.

now build up whole clock together: remove the hands and use two screws at top (left and right) to connect the clockwork with clock face mount to the clock face. The best would be lying it down between two tables like this so clock hands are between in open space. Please do not lay it down on axis it will move optical stop position.

11. finished

The main idea is very simple: just use stepper motors instead of more complicated gear and control speed of them independently. Also just ball bearings for the axis. As I never had done something like this before it turned out as a project which took several months for me. Each part has been printed and tested around 3-5 times. This are the prototype parts I designed and printed:

• which 3D printer is recommended?
    I used the CR-10 because it has got large build plate.

  • what should I do first?
    I recommend to get DCF module running first or another time signal solution (e.g. NTP over Wifi) for your country/location. After that you could do the clockwork+electronics and after everything runs with testing clock hands you can buy clock face+print clock hands.

  • can I print the castle as well ?
    Not with CR-10 in original size but if you have the right printer for this job, drop me a note so I might print another one :)

  • What is DCF time module and where can it be used?
    I used DCF time signal because it is most reliable source to get exact time without having internet here in Germany.
    Also I am not planning to move with my castle somewhere else .. so this is best solution for me :)
    It should be not too difficult to change code for other time solution. Also that module is separated from main electronics to swap it out for another one. In US or most other countries you cannot use DCF signal but in Europe in several ones I guess.

  • Can you help me for another clock face, hands, other changes?
    Sorry but I have no time for this but I included this instructions and Fusion 360 files so you could do it yourself.

  • Which is maximum size for hands/diameter of clock face?
    In this project minute hand has got length around 50 cm for 91 cm clock face. I think this can be scaled up easily to 1,3m diameter.
    For clock faces 2m or above the stepper motors might be changed to stronger ones so some parts of clockwork have to be recreated in fusion 360. Also separate power supply for this motors might help as well. If you are not sure just construct one big hand and make some tests. Do not forget to balance hand with some weights. With CR-10 printer a strong clock hand could be printed in three parts for very long minute hand (2m clock face diameter).

  • Can I use longer axis because I have thick clock face (like old wood wheel)?
    yes just use longer metal rod.

    • Can I hang such a clock on wall at home?
      yes but clockworks is about 15cm in depth so it stands up a bit from wall.

    • Which other clock faces can you recommend?
      anything what you want in real size:

      Some back illuminated clock face might be nice as well)

  • How does it work to be always in time?
    to be honest without correction algorithm it would not be very precise but minute adjust itself every hour and hours twice a day.
    So a winter/summer time change will be shown at 12 o clock at the moment. This could be changed in code. As there might some tolerances at minute hand gears so this one might have around one minute late ion time. You could tight up gears a bit more to solve this.

  • How reliable does it work:
    I am running this now for about 4 weeks just from the first mount without any error but I do not have longer running experience now.
    Also what happened in hot summer.

  • What is most important to thinks about making this?

    • ask for cutting of 3cm square in clock face
    • never let clock fall on its axis. This will shift it out of position and you have to adjust it again which takes a lot of time.
    • do not over tighten the screws it will break up the printed plastic
  • Which material should I print?
    if you are using it inside PLA is fine otherwise better ASA,ABS or PETG. ASA might be the best choice.

description.text:
Great for school, work, or any other situation where you need to wield a pencil in style. This pencil case holds 1-2 pens or pencils and can be customized (within fusion 360) to be the exact right size for the pencils you want to hold. I wanted to have a new pencil case for school and this is what I came up with. It stores a Hi-Polymer Block Eraser (the smaller black ones) as well as pencils. The magnets (10mm x 3mm, can be changed in fusion 360) have opposite polarities on opposite sides so the case can't be closed backwards and the two pieces of the case will stack when the case is opened. This could be 3d-printed as well.

This is my first real project with CNC milling besides work-holding and test piece and begins my adventure in milling useful items. The work was done on a Shapeoko 3.

description.header: CNC - Stock, Cutters, Feeds and speeds
description.text:
Stock

This was milled out of 2, 3/4in thick pieces of poplar.

Cutter

All of the milling was done using Carbide3D's #201 3 flute 1/4in flat end mill.

Feeds and Speeds

30-45 ipm depending on the cut
15000 RPM
0.15" maximum DOC
40% - 100% radial engagement

Magnets

The holes in the case are just a little bit too deep for that magnets. This means that the force of that magnets is not too strong and the case is easier to open but, it is also convenient for gluing in the magnets. I just put a dab of UV curable glue (epoxy might work too) around the rim of the magnet after I put it into its hole. I also made sure that the magnets on opposite sides will repel one another so the case can't close backwards.

Sanding

I snapped the box together and used a belt sander to make the edges of each piece flush with one another. For the inside, I just used a piece of hand sand paper.

Finishing

I put 2 coats of a clear polyurethane onto my case using a piece of 220 grit sand paper in between.

remixed_from.title: On Air Sign (Desk or Horizontal Mount)

title: Stupid Segoe UI Black Font with Oversized "holes" for placing them.

description.text:
Ok, I feel silly posting this, but maybe it'd help. Lots of apps make it "easy" to add a letter to things, but it's harder to make a recess to hold a letter if you print the letter separately. The hole needs to be a little bigger, but you can't just scale up the letter because then the hollow parts of things like A & O get bigger in the wrong direction.

So, the idea here is that people could put the "holes" on their model and then print the letters separately.

They work OK scaled down to 80%, haven't tried lower than that. (Too much smaller and letters get hard to print). They should scale up fine, but the holes will start getting too big.

Frankly, it might be easier to just redo it with an apporpriate string/font than use my letters. But maybe this'll help someone.

SketchUp has an extension "RoundCorner" with a "bevel" feature.

I placed a big rectangle around my letters and streched it up so that I had recessed letters (at least the height of the bevel).

Then I selected everything and told it to bevel it with 0.5mm.

You'll have to clean up wherever the letters bevel faces intersected.

Then you can delete the lower bits, leaving only the 0.5mm too-large outlines. Which you can then use to extrude holes.

Created and printed this as part of upgrading my Tarantula. I ordered some end stop switches that were much higher quality and had removable wires. No soldering required and they don't break off the way the stock ones tend to do. The mounting holes may be tight when you print depending on how accurate your printer is.

IMPORTANT: The stock endstop switches will not fit on this. This was specifically designed to work with the switches in the Amazon link below.

The brackets are based on the original bracket with the mounting points moved to match the new end stops.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01NB9H4CY (if link doesn't work, search for "3D Printer parts Kossel Limit Switches Endstop with 1m/3-feet Long Cable" )

This redesigned x-belt tensioner makes a couple of adjustments for the Anet A8 kit i bought in Q4 2017.

  • Increased the distance between the outer dimensions of the two arms that insert into the x-axis holder to prevent it moving vertically

My design for a case for my component tester I have added 3 holes to use the pads and a break out panel so the leads can be used should they be needed.
I had to bend the bar on the socket and I suggest if you do it you take it out of the socket and use some pliers otherwise you could destroy the socket, its a bit awkward to put it back together but a needle and patience will get it back together.
I did intend to put some screw through to hold the back on but mine slots in and hold really solidly so I didnt bother.
Also I put a little bit of foam to hold the battery firmly in place.
Enjoy!

I thought I would add some info not directly concerning the print but the tester itself that I found quite by accident as I never got any documentation with it.
If you press and hold the test button you get a menu with various other functions like frequency counter/generator. Now you clever folk may already know this but it was a complete surprise for me.

Power Button - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01I9KDVWQ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

You need to have your power button connected to the Common (C) and Normally Open (NO) connectors. The LED needs to be connected to the - and + terminal.

author: avies

description.text:
This is a Geodesic dome created in Openscad. I was teaching myself Openscad so it's not the greatest code. It's setup for 1/8" wooden dowels such as wooden food skewers you find at the store. The blue and red connector's are indicated in the printed object with a bump near the socket (or lack if its a red connector).

Note, I followed the 2V design from this site: http://geo-dome.co.uk/2v_tool.asp
Note: I used a 1/8th inch drill bit to manually wallow out the connector holes where necessary, there is some variation in the skewer diameters.

To make higher quality prints I did all of them upright, which meant I had to split the 5-way and 6-way connectors in half. When assembling the dome I do the bottom layer first, then move up layers, when it's finally connected I come back with a hot-glue gun and glue the halves together.

I'm using this dome for a 360 degree diversity FPV antenna holder. Some facets have a directional antenna on them, all feed down into their own RX5808 module which will find the strongest signal and select that video feed.

Each blue connector (the slightly longer one of the 2 connector bars) has a bump printed near the socket. Each red connector does not. I found it best to take a magic marker and mark each wooden stick after you cut them with either a red marker or blue depending on which length you cut.
Openscad

Pyramid game pieces (icehouse, treehouse, Looney Pyramids) designed according to the official specifications

These pieces have been designed according to the official Looney Labs specifications for Looney Pyramids. I have included a 5x5 board for Volcano and Caldera as well as a 6x6 board for MegaVolcano. Additionally, a 2x3 board is available.

Based on a recommendation, we started using a token system with our children. When they do chores or things we want to encourage, they earn tokens. Tokens can be turned in for privileges or lost if they misbehave.

Initially checkers from the dollar store were used, but it quickly became cumbersome as it wasn't intuitive which tokens were used by which child.

This is my 3d printed solution. Each token has a child's initial and the colors are more closely aligned to their favorite colors. The tokens have about the same dimensions as the original checkers (23mm diameter, 3mm height, 0.5mm lettering height). The blank token was design in Fusion 360. The letters were added using OpenSCAD as it is simpler to center them there than in 360.

Since I only have a single extruder, the second color is added via the M600 command and Prusa's color print utility. I manually move the command farther down in the gcode to improve the print quality of the output. These are my first multi-color prints.
