author: stavrosg

description.text:
This implements a modification of Reiter's hex cell snowflake growth algorithm in BlocksCAD. The algorithm uses a real-valued cellular automaton modeling the diffusion and accretion of moisture. When run at high resolution, the model can produce surprisingly lifelike snowflakes, but BlocksCAD can't handle more than about radius 50 (and even that is laggy) of hex grid for the evolution.

I strongly recommend using Firefox instead of Chrome for these large BlocksCAD projects. Firefox is much more responsive.

The model has these main parameters:

  • alpha: controls moisture diffusion speed
  • beta: controls background moisture level (with optional random local variation)
  • gamma: controls accretion rate at frozen locations (with optional random temporal variation)

The random variation modifications, which aren't in the original Reiter algorithm, have ended up producing very nice effects--or at least the beta variation has (the gamma variation seems not to do as much).

There are four versions of the BlocksCAD code: radius 20, radius 30, radius 40 and radius 50. Up to radius 40, it works fine on Firefox, and on Chrome up to radius 30. Radius 50 is laggy on Firefox, and I haven't even tried it on Chrome. Firefox is much faster for BlocksCAD.

You can vary the thickness of the snowflake based on the simulated mass value at a given point for a further 3D effect (change the min_thickness to be less than the max_thickness for this effect), or you can introduce symmetric ridges for a pleasing visual 3D effect (make the ridge_angle be something like 3-10 degrees).

The snowflakes are readily printable--see photos. I recommend a thickness of about 2.5mm, and using a razor to scrape the flake off the printer bed.

The Thingiverse customizer was produced by exporting the code from BlocksCAD to OpenSCAD and moving the parameters to the top. Exported OpenSCAD code also generated the animation and the mosaic.

BlocksCAD does not support arrays. And it's a functional language. The evolution is thus handled by having a gigantic evolve module, which takes 421 arguments (in the radius 40 version): the iteration count, and the data for all the 420 cells being simulated (only 1/12 of the full board needs to be simulated--the rest is reconstructed by symmetry). The module then calls itself recursively, with a decremented iteration count and with evolved cells. Because of the lack of arrays, each cell's evolution has a hard-coded call to a cell evolution function. Once iteration count reaches zero, all the cells that count as frozen (data value at least 1) are drawn, as well as their (typically) 11 symmetric copies, by the draw module.

There is also a big go module that initializes the arguments for evolve.

While one could, though it would be crazy to, drag-and-drop all the hard-coded evolution code, I just wrote a python script (included: the main code is reiter.scad) that generates the BlocksCAD xml for the evolve and go modules. The drawing code, the individual cell evolution code, and the parameter initialization code was hand-written in BlocksCAD.

https://youtu.be/kZH0ZB992ZY
https://youtu.be/812HeHZrEhk

print_settings.Notes:: Regular PLA is very brittle, I do not recommend it... You can try, but be prepared to re-print after the first crash ;)

description.text:
Designed from scratch in Fusion360 and meticulously optimized for minimal weight without sacrificing strength. Prints without any supports.

I use elastic bands to hold the 150-250mAh 1S LiPo batteries. Battery mount in the pics kind of worked, looks pretty, but is too fragile. I'm working on the next version of a battery mount.

Motors are pressure-fit. This is a little tricky and may require some carefully directed force, and success will depend on your print quality. I've found that if the motor doesn't go in, you can warm it up (not too much!), and it will soften the PLA on the way in. No idea about ABS. Any suggestions re: improvements to motor mounts are welcome.

My build (display in pictures):

  • 6x15mm motors: https://tinyurl.com/y83tvw2u
  • BeeCore F3 flight controller: https://tinyurl.com/yb95b8xr
  • 31mm propellers: https://tinyurl.com/y8g9xn2d

Please feel free to use my affiliate links above if you'd like to build one of your own, using the same parts :)

title: Drop-in laser engraving bracket for Monoprice Select Mini

description.text:
This is a printable bracket for a cheaply available 1000mw engraving laser, driven directly by the fan controller for the Monoprice Select Mini printer. Once connection wires are spliced, it's a drop in replacement for the factory fan. The same spring clips that hold the fan apply clip to the sides. Remove the fan, slide the laser into the bracket, clip the bracket, and connect the wiring.

At full power it draws about 1300mw (including fan).

This is designed for a 33mm square laser assembly with built in cooling fan, such as:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2500mw-Laser-Module-450NM-Focusing-Blue-Laser-Head-Laser-Engraving-2-5w-Laser-Tube-Diode-hx2/32797453297.html

(you wouldn't need the 2500mw - I thought I might want room to grow ;)

Gcode to turn the fan off:
M106 S0

Full power:
M106 S255

You set the Length, Wiidth, Height, and wall/floor thickness
You may specify inside or outside dimensions.

Nothing fancy, just an easy way to generate the right size box.

My apologies for the first OpenSCAD program I uploaded. I had forgotten to fix a small problem. It was generating non-manifold objects. After trying to fix tkat problem for several hours, I decided to try a different approach, and used an MCAD library called boxes.scad, which proved to be a much better solution.

http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2014/07/11/weekendmake-make-excavator-larger-life/
Enjoy!
This design is included in our Gumball Collection.

Our gum ball is printed at standard resolution and 3% infill. It took 45 minutes to print.
Printing Instructions For MakerBot Mini
=============================
If connected via WI-FI:

• On the Thing page, click on Thing Files to see available files.
    Click on the part or version you want to print to download the thing to your computer. Click on the file once downloaded. MakerBot Desktop will open and the file you selected will appear on the build plate.
  • Click the Print button to slice your model. To send the file to your MakerBot Replicator Mini and exit the Print dialog, click Start Print.
  • When the print file is sent to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, the Action Button will blink blue. Press the Action Button to confirm the print. The Action Button will then glow red, indicating it is heating the MakerBot Replicator Smart Extruder. When the Smart Extruder is fully heated, the MakerBot Replicator Mini will start to print your model.
  • When your print finishes, wait for the Smart Extruder to cool, then remove the build plate from the MakerBot Replicator Mini. Remove the print from the build plate, and peel off the raft from the bottom of the print.
  • Every object printed on your MakerBot Replicator Mini will be built on a raft. The raft acts as a base for your object and any support structures, and ensures that everything adheres well to the build plate. The raft will be easily removable once you remove your finished object from the build plate.
  • You're almost done. Go enjoy your weekend and take your newly printed friend with you. Take a few creative photos and upload them to Thingiverse as a Make by clicking I Made One above.
    If connected via USB:
  • On the Thing page, click on Thing Files to see available files.
    Click on the part or version you want to print to download the thing to your computer. Click on the file once downloaded. MakerBot Desktop will open and the file you selected will appear on the build plate.
  • Click the Print button to slice your model. To send the file to your MakerBot Replicator Mini and exit the Print dialog, click Start Print.
  • If you decide not to send the file to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, click Cancel Print.
  • When the print file is sent to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, the Action Button will glow red, indicating it is heating the MakerBot Replicator Smart Extruder. When the Smart Extruder is fully heated, the MakerBotReplicator Mini will start to print your model.
  • When your print finishes, wait for the Smart Extruder to cool, then remove the build plate from the MakerBot Replicator Mini. Remove the print from the build plate, and peel off the raft from the bottom of the print.
  • Every object printed on your MakerBot Replicator Mini will be built on a raft. The raft acts as a base for your object and any support structures, and ensures that everything adheres well to the build plate. The raft will be easily removable once you remove your finished object from the build plate.
  • You're almost done. Go enjoy your weekend and take your newly printed friend with you. Take a few creative photos and upload them to Thingiverse as a Make by clicking I Made One above.

description.text:
When I was making some adjustments to my printer, I put too much pressure on the USB cable on my Creality CR-10 and damaged the connector. To avoid this issue and support the connector, I threw this together in TinkerCAD. I've included the gcode files for the CR-10 to print it at 205 deg so you can print it out right away. Even though the top mount version is pictured and what I used, I also included a modified side mount version that I think would provide better support and has a slightly tighter fit for the plug. You could also add some tape around the plug to get the right fit.

To attach to your printer control box, simply place a dab of super glue above and below the opening on the flat surface that will make contact with the control box. Slip the cable through the support and connect it to the port. Then slide the support up around the cable and press firmly to the control box. If using the top mount version, just place the super glue on the inside top surface that will make contact with the top of the control box. This worked like a charm for me. If using the side mount version, place the super glue above and below the opening. Hope it helps. Don't forget to check for fit before adding the glue, though.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40 or 100

Notes:

The top mount version prints with supports and 40% infill at 205. The side mount version prints at 100% infill since the walls on it are thinner and also prints at 205.

comments.text: This is something Im surprised I dont see more of. The USB connector on the main-board is so weak - I almost broke mine the first week from a defective cable that came with the CR-10S. Makes me miss the USB-B (full size like a printer uses) connectors for these. USB mini's/Micros are just too weak for these things.

author: goofdad

title: Bondtech BMG Upper Mount for Ultibots D300VS or SeeMeCNC Max

description.text:
This is a BondTech BMG extruder mount for the Ultibots D300VS that sits above the effector plane, giving more Z printing height and also potentially minimizing acceleration wobble of the nozzle. This should work with SeeMeCNC Max printers or any other delta with a 50mm ball-ball spacing. Hot end is a E3D V6. A Volcano should work as well.

With this mount, I have over 500mm of build height on my D300VS.

The Bondtech BMG is a really nice extruder. It is well designed and the dual driven hob pushes filament like no other.

There are 2 versions of this mount. One that uses ball studs and another that uses SeeMeCNC nylon barbells, and should work with the machined aluminum barbells available from SeeMeCNC.

The nylon barbells have a consistent ball-to-ball distance, but unfortunately, they flex quite a bit, leading to ringing on direction changes. With the metal balls I see about 1/2 the wavy ringing on direction changes.

Ball studs:
https://www.ultibots.com/ball-studs-set-of-12-non-magnetic/

Nylon barbells
https://www.seemecnc.com/collections/parts-accessories/products/replacement-ball-joints

Machined barbells
https://www.seemecnc.com/collections/parts-accessories/products/cnc-machined-ball-joint-kit

Cooling is performed by a 4020 blower fan. The fan is mounted above the stepper and body of the mount is the manifold. You can install up to 8 4mm aluminum tubes that descend from the effector base for part cooling. I have had good luck with 6 of them installed. Drill out the plugged holes with a 4mm bit for the tubes you wish to populate. Fix with a dab of CA adhesive The aluminum tubing is 4mm diam x 0.45 wall. I bought this via amazon, though it is out of stock now. Should be available at hobby stores.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005WPAJUE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Print the mandrel and roller parts and bend the aluminum tubing. It may require some sanding, tweaking, pinching and cutting to get the aluminum shaped correctly. Press them into the drilled holes on the bottom of the effector and optionally secure with some CA adhesive.

Copper or brass should also work. Stainless (available from mcmaster.com) is too hard to easily bend, though you may have better luck packing the tube with sand or using a torch to bend.

This design requires a 20mm thick pancake Nema17 stepper. A 25mm thick might work, but it may interfere with the Z column arms. 20mm stepper at 800mA & 24V works just fine and doesn't skip steps. I got mine from steppers online:

https://www.omc-stepperonline.com/hybrid-stepper-motor/nema-17-bipolar-18deg-13ncm-184ozin-1a-35v-42x42x20mm-4-wires-17hs08-1004s.html

There is provision for a 2mm dia rod to function as a strain relief mast for the wires leading to the effector. Drill that out if necessary.

Note, that to get things to not interfere, I had to move the nozzle 20mm forwards of the centerpoint. This wlll slightly reduce the print area. If using Duet3D, add the following to your config.g file:
G10 P0 X0 Y-20 ; for offset BMG extruder

Here's all my config changes for this:
M92 E421 ; From motor calibration via mhackneys calibration tool. Your's may be different
M906 X1000 Y1000 Z1000 E800 ; Bondtch set motor currents to 800mA for 20mm pancake (mA)
G10 P0 X0 Y-20 ; BMG Upper has nozzle 20mm offset. Compensate for that. (edited)

You will also need to edit homedelta.g to lower the carriages down a bit so the 20mm offset can be accomplished without bumping the endstops.
Change the G1 Z-XX line to:
G1 Z-15 F2000 ; down a few mm so that we can centre the head

calibration tool:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2598993

Finally, slice this with Slic3r PE using the "Support on Build Plate Only" checkbox selected in the Support Material tab. This prevents it from infilling the manifolds with support material. Also uncheck Support Bridges. I haven't found a way to do the same in KissSlicer.

Printer:

Ultibots D300VS

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Best to print with a higher temp plastic. I used Carbon Fiber Atomic PETG.
Designed using Fusion 360. See attached archive file. I'm still new at Fusion 360, so it kinda became a bit of a mess near the end.

title: SUBARU WRX STI AOS CATCH CAN FULLY PRINTABLE

description.text:
this is my first upload im a total noob to 3d design this is a design based on a part i already fabricate and the design works very well i have not used a 3d printed version yet so use at your own risk!

i have scaled everything to fit pretty well ive included test items for you to print and check the scaling of the threaded parts if you choose to print this id appreciate if you leave my logos on it if your going to print it and sell you absolutely must keep my logos on it thats all i ask!

everything should be easily printed without supports id suggest going with a little lower then normal extruder temp and run cooling at 100% so the threaded parts come out nice.
i added a version of the top and bottom half with supports for threads please print it.
do NOT add support in your slicer you dont want a bunch of extra junk inside the can that could come loose and end up in your engine.

I would also suggest using orings on all the fittings to insure an air tight seal i dont want to hear any blown ringland stories lol lol

check out rocksteadytuning.com for all my wrx and sti parts!

12/31/17 update added top and bottom of catch can with supports for the threaded bungs i test printed it and the support snaps right out as planned and the fittings thread in perfectly now! also added file with the can assembled with some simple directions embossed on it!
added a new pcv adapter with built in supports just print it with a brim and when its done twist the the support piece and pull it out!

all the pieces and parts have been test printed i would just strongly suggest printing all the pieces one at a time. do not try to print the assembled cans it will not work.

1/2/18 updated the bracket to add some strength and made the fittings a little larger to better fit 1/2 inch hose.

Printer:

anet a8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100

Infill:

20-60

Notes:

i would test print the big parts at about 50% to make sure everything comes out as planned
also test print the bung and fitting threads to make sure they mate up properly.
NGSS CCSS
aos ive made many aos for subarus this is just a printable design
install and print aos install aos

youll need a 2.5 inch hose clamp 8 small #8 hose clamps and about 5-10 feet of 1/2 inch hose
a few 1/2 inch caps and also a 1/4 npt plug for under your throttle body

print_settings.Notes:: Its a box... go hog wild and use it as a calibration cube/box :P

description.text: My TV stand is only so big, and my old LCD TV has a HUGE baseplate, so I had to raise my new soundbar in order to clear the stand and have room for a HDMI switcher. 3D printer to the rescue! This was meant for Vizio soundbars with 50mm square rubber feet. Ya need 2 prints, unless you really like to balance things.

Notes:

Its a box... go hog wild and use it as a calibration cube/box :P

Character Model from Overwatch.
Proportions have been changed to be appropriate for a wargame or RPG.
Glue to a 25mm base.

I really like the spool holder and I've printed two copies over time. Both of them were extremely hard to put over the 12mm rods. So I grabbed the original and cut out slightly larger holes. Works great. I think I went a little deeper than the original though, but the OpenSCAD file is there if you'd like to change anything.

The way I made sure the cut outs were on the the same centers is by doing an intersection of the two parts and then making small adjustments until the intersection was a perfect circle (just change difference to intersection and you'll see what I mean).

Not sure anyone is still nursing an old Printrbot like this one but me, however, this would fit any machine with some 12mm rods poking up like that.

Oh, you need the little socket piece from the original design (see the remixed from).

P.S. The OpenSCAD preview is dumb because Thingiverse can't import the original STL, which you'll need to download if you want to recut it.

print_settings.Notes:: No need for supports or in-fills.

title: Dual 50mm cooling fans mount for any MKS board

description.text:
Simple no-frills frame for mounting 2 x 50mm fans that you screw down onto ply-board mounting next to your MKS board. Works with basically any MKS board as it's not attached directly. It was specifically designed to work optimised for MKS Base 1.4 board to give maximum cooling to the servo drivers.

You will also need to print out 2 x these fan mounts : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1092129

author: jaydeelocs

description.text:
I have to say it. I love my new Sunbeam Torino. If you are looking to pull the plug and buy one of these, you wont regret it! I'm a barista by trade and this little machine rivals the industrial unit we use at work.

Anyways; I discovered the height of first world problems yesterday and decided to use my printer to fix it. The grinder that sunbeam ships with this machine has a slight concavity that catches collected or spilt grounds before/after tamping. It works great...but how do you get the grounds out and to the bin? This is where my dish comes in. Using a dry paintbrush, just brush them into the dish and voila! problem solved. No more having to unplug the entire grinder just to clean out the grounds.

I have made two versions of the dish (a large and a small) and I would highly recommend using the large version as it makes the dish that much more functional as it can wrap around the sides. :) My printer has quite a small build volume so I printed and use the small version as pictured.

Happy printing!

I've also included the freecad file, so if so desired you can easily make this taller or shorter by adjusting the length of the padding of the legs.

title: Fixed-Position Web Cam Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed to collect some data that required my web cam be setup in the exact same position every time, so I designed this camera mount. It's built to be rigid and deterministic. Rather than relying purely on friction to clamp it in place it has teeth that lock into each other and require intentionally loosening the bolts to change angles. It attaches to a small corner bracket that aligns with the outer corner of my printer, guaranteeing that the web cam is always aligned the same.

The bolts are #10-32 x 1.25". The mount is designed for a Microsoft LifeCam HD-3000, but it could easily be adapted for other cameras. The corner piece is sized for a Monoprice Select Mini v2. It was designed in Fusion 360.

author: snyz

title: Monoprice v2.1 Y Bar Alignment Jig i3 Maker Select Wanhao

description.text:
Bed level is such a big issue! But bed level is much affected by the alignment of things. Lets just be real. They were just slapped together before they left the factory. So getting everything nice and straight is what we need to do.

But who wanta to sit there with calipers to get everything perfect?

Holding calipers, holding the fame, holding the rods, tightening the bolts. You need an extra set of hands. But im lazy, i like simple. This is a version2. First print 2 jigs. Then get your printer on a nice flat surface. Remove the gantey (like how you got it when it was shipped to you).

Remove the heated bed, and check the springs are even height. Crazy off height puts excess tension on the lower plate (not good).

Remove the lower plate - if you see its warped, simply flatten it back out. Most likely warped from the factory.

Losen the rod bolts and the grub screws (if you dont have grub screws, get them, otherwise the rods are not completely stationary). Place the frame on your surface, and all 4 corners should be contacting. If not, loosen the bolts and get your main frame straight and flat.
Originally these jigs were designed to be flipped from the picture and go under the belts so all 4 corners would be at equal heights. But there is only .5-1mm of play in the bolt holes, and there is a thick coating applied to the printers frame that threw off distances. So my coating/your coating blah blah mines worn, yours isnt. Ideally you want the Y rods level with your base because your Z motors are also sitting on that same surface. So equally shim each corner with paper, or you can just flip the jigs as shown - i had miminal height variances by sitting the jigs on top due to the coating.

Tighten the grub screws first, then SLOWLY and evenly tighten the rest of the rod bolts..

Placing your lower plate on the bars should be flat, pressing each corner you will notice if any other corner pops up, if it does, either your rods are not perfect, or your lower plate is warped, adjust as needed.

Attach the lower plate loosly, and feel it move.. feel it move front/back.. Grab each block and again, evenly and slowly tighten the screws for the bearing blocks.. If you just tighten one and then the next, the block will twist and cause drag.. Then reassemble the rest of the printer. You should now notice the 4 springs have an almost equal compression to them. Which in turn will resuly in far less bed relevels. Even with the stock thumb wheels (which i still use).

comments.text: I read details 5 times. Still not getting this procedure. Sorry.
comments.author: Shurak

comments.text:
Sorry about the late reply.
What part is confusing? So i can re-word it. It needs to be understandable to beginners. Most of the vets know how to align it without printing these things. Feel free to shoot me a message. And well get it all layed out.
comments.author: Shurak

comments.text: I align it by the distance from the top of the Y rod to the table. Caliper or dial gauge, gets me to about 0.05 mm, could be better with some patience. Did not care much about horizontal alignment though. Would like to see how veterans do it.
comments.author: Modified_Gemini

comments.text: When i designed the jigs it was for both parallel and vertical alignment. When the jigs are fliped to the bottom theyre dssigned to fit under the belt and supposed to contact the floor. Unfortunately the printer parts are dipped in a thick coating. Which changed the distance.. So you would have to EQUALLY shim each corner of the jig (not printer base) with paper. Like 2/3 sheets.. I had instances where one corner of the jig touched the surface while the other didnt..
comments.author: Shurak

comments.text: Thank you, it is clear now. Printer frame should be positioned on the flat surface with all four down. Y rods unscrewed, pegs under them. Pegs to be shimmed equally on each corner such a way that Y rods fully rest on them and not on the frame. Then gradually tighten the screws.

title: Catnip Yarn Ball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
About

My plastic loving cat decided that he likes the smell of PLA and wants to eat it. This gave me the idea of making a toy for him, and there's no beating the classic image of a cat playing with a ball of yarn!

Printing

  • Printed at 0.2mm.
  • Print with supports.
  • Keep the open end face up so that the supports do not fill up the bowl.
  • Fusion 360 file included for easy editing. There are parameters for the outer wall thickness, the catnip hole size, ring thickness & size (so you can easily adjust it if you have a different kind/size of yarn), and a tolerance for the male plug (so you can change it based on your printer's tolerance/how it prints).

Putting it together

  • Use a very very long piece of yarn, maybe 30+ feet. I ran out a lot quicker than I thought I would.
  • The holes are only for starting the wrap. I wouldn't advise putting more than one line through them because it should be covered at the end.
  • Wrap the yarn under the previous wrapped lines every few wraps. If you try to wrap too much without securing it, then if it comes undone it will all come undone.
    Wrapping it properly is actually the hardest part. It is better to have too much string than too little so you can cover everything completely and secure it.

title: Hakko T12 adapter for the TS100 Soldering Iron

description.text:
This little adapter lets you use Hakko T12/T15 tips on your TS100 soldering iron. (T12/T15 are the same, just for different markets) Of course, your iron will be longer, but the upshot is that the Hakko tips can be had for cheaper, and the little rubber grip on the Hakko has a lot better feel than the body of the TS100.

The adapter includes a built-in stand.

I was able to print it without any supports by printing with the stand end face down. Once you are done, slide the rubber grip on a Hakko tip and click it into place, and then click the adapter into the rubber tip. Loosen the Allen bolt on the iron and slide it into the iron. It'll only fit one way. Lock it down gently with the Allen bolt and you're good to go. This area on the iron does not heat up, so printing with PLA is just fine.

Included is the Solidworks source file.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini v1

print_settings.Notes:: Nothing special here. Print lying flat with the groove facing up. Consider compatibility with hot glue when choosing your material. PLA has the advantage of being dead cheap and builds a strong bond to hot glue. You could even think about a medium flexibility TPE or TPU.

description.text:
Get the hang of it.
Hotglue this Thing to anything that has no hook on it and needs to be put on a wall: medals, plates, lamps, gadgets, clothes, tools, even picture frames! Compatible with nails AND screws!!

Nailits are single use since it is unbearable to pry the hot glue from the gripping holes.

For one Nailit, printing time with 100% infill is 6 minutes, cost in PLA is 0,04€

Suitable for all objects which are hot-glueable. Removes without a trace if finished with hanging.

Sensible use of hotglue is advised. Use appropriate safety gear and do not touch hot and liquid glue. Do not try to hang objects whith bad adhesion to hot glue or if you are unsure if the glue can hold the weight. The glue is the part that will fail, not the Nailit.
Disclaimer: I do not recommend or encourage putting up heavy objects and am not liable for damages or injuries if they drop. It's in your own judgement what you put up.
I hung the bass just for the thrills and did not dare to walk away:)

Enjoy! Go bananas!

Printer:

CR-10

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Nothing special here. Print lying flat with the groove facing up. Consider compatibility with hot glue when choosing your material. PLA has the advantage of being dead cheap and builds a strong bond to hot glue. You could even think about a medium flexibility TPE or TPU.

How to use:

Give the freshly printed Nailit a slight bend where the groove is. Don't worry if it feels like it's breaking. It won't. Better not bend it after its glued to an object or it will come loose. The pre-Bending gives it some flexibility for reaching the nail even from behind objects with recessed or concave backsides. Apply a pea-sized glob of hot glue to the desired object in a suitable spot, press in the Nailit with the part where the holes are and the groove facing away from the object. You'll want some hot glue squirting out of the holes.
Not entirely necessary step: wait until the glue is cooler and no longer sticky but still soft and give it a short press to "rivet" the squirted hot glue.

title: GH60 / Satan mechanical keyboard three piece minimalistic frame

description.text:
Three piece minimalistic keyboard frame for GH60 PCB, can be printed with smaller printers than full sized keyboard frames (longest side of parts is less than 100mm) and is really good for testing and even normal everyday use. Frame pieces are tight fit, but there are screwholes to attach pieces with some regular plastic screws.

If you are building this keyboard you need GH60 keyboard PCB, keyboard switches and key caps set. Soldering switches to PCB without positioning board can be quite tricky but it's definitely doable.

Keyboard works really well and is surprisingly good to use. Even without full frame supporting the PCB it is not flexing too much and keyboard is really sturdy. Some table surfaces can be quite slippery against PLA parts and keyboard might slip. Maybe in future i could update model to allow some anti slipping pads, or frame parts can be painted with some rubbery coating (plastidip or similar) to avoid slipping and improving looks.

This is a simple design of a magnet fishing net handle. It is designed for that kind of fishing net that is attached to the rod with a thread.
I thought it would be nice to be able to use my fishing net with the long rod for fishing from shore as well with a short handle for fly and wadefishing.
It consist of two parts with build in magnets that have to be inserted during the print.
The fishing net is attached with a threaded sleeve that has to be inserted during the print aswell.

Material:

  • 2x neodym magnets 18x5mm
  • 1x m10 threaded sleeve 13x30mm
  • 1x carabiner or clip
  • leather stripe or other cord
  • heat-shrink tubing

Before I started printing I checked the correct height in my slicing program to make sure I can stop the print at the right time to insert the magnets or the sleeve.
You can just slide the magnet in once you stopped the print and moved the nozzle aside.
Before you insert the magnets make sure to insert the them with the right orientation so that they don't push each other away.

title: Endcaps for telescopic shower bar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had to replace the endcaps of my showerbar (old, became yellow and... broken).
There are 2 endcaps : one for the 18mm diameter end of the tube, the other for the 20 mm diameter end.
Inside the endcap, the shape is carved around so the tube cannot move when fixing the bar to the wall.

Printed with a flexible filament, works perfectly.
I did not try printing with ABS or PLA.

According to the diameter of the tubes, one may resize the parts with the slicer for adaptation.
